title: YuE: Scaling Open Foundation Models for Long-Form Music Generation
author: HKUST and MAP, ..., Haohe Liu (University of Surrey)
relevance_why: The work introduces innovative methods and models for music generation, particularly in the context of lyrics-to-song performance, which is highly relevant to my research in audio and speech processing.
background: This paper addresses the challenge of generating long-form music, specifically converting lyrics into full songs with coherent musical structures, vocal melodies, and instrumental accompaniment.
contribution: YuE introduces a unique framework leveraging advanced tokenization and conditioning strategies to improve lyrics-to-song generation, achieving high-quality music outputs up to five minutes long.

technical_comparison.prior_work: Previous models struggled with generating coherent full-length songs and often produced low-quality audio outputs limited to short durations.
technical_comparison.novelty: YuE improves upon these limitations by implementing track-decoupled next-token prediction and structural progressive conditioning, resulting in better musical coherence and quality.

key_innovation: The dual-token strategy allows for independent modeling of vocals and accompaniment, enhancing the clarity and musical quality of generated music.
real_world_impact: This work has the potential to democratize music creation, making it accessible to a broader audience and fostering new innovative approaches to musical expression in technology.
limitations: The paper does not explicitly mention any limitations.

new_terms.lyrics-to-song: **Lyrics-to-song** refers to the process of transforming written lyrics into complete musical compositions, which include vocal and instrumental arrangements.
